Also has a soft carry case and comes with about 110 rnds of ammo, about 45 being hornaday hollowpoints. This is a really nice concealed piece, weighing in at just over 6oz unloaded. Pretty open to any other firearms if it catches my interest so feel free to message me on here or text REDACTED with offers. First pic shows everything, second shows the P32 in a front pocket of the tightest jeans I have (I dont wear them ever due to that fact) to show that it only looks like a pocket knife at a glance. title: For Sale:  ww2 mg34
postcontent: This is a once and a life time chance to own a real piece of ww2 history. I was stationed in Baumholder Germany for four years. During this time I met a ww2 german vet who found this mg34 in a field just out side of town. He said there was a lot of heavy fighting there. THIS GUN DOES NOT AND WILL NEVER FIRE. This is considered a battle field relic. The gun is heavy. I would say 45 pounds. The flash suppresser still unscrews. The feed tray is in bad shape and comes off. All the guts are rusted to the point that they are un-usable or restorable. The wooden butt stock is also gone. The bi-pod still moves freely. The gun measures at 44 inch. This is a real gun from a real battle field. Who knows the stories it could tell. Please look at the pics carefully. What you see is what you get. I do not have any paper work on it. If you want I can show you my military orders to Baumholder Germany. I also have the aerial site for it. There are no markings on the gun. Someone did paint it green to stop it from rusting. Very cool piece of history just for show. Email with questions. Low ball offers will be ignored. $1000 OBO

title: Want To Buy:  Rifles
postcontent:
There sure are a lot of rude ass people on here. If you put your gun up for sale or trade there is no reason to be an ass about what you want for it. With poor salesmanship and piss poor manners your angry adds make me find other sellers. Oh and tip, why would I purchase a rifle for what you might think yours is worth when I can get one at one or our local shops for less money and it is new? 

Think about stuff before you post it. Be polite and respectful and you just may get my hard earned cash. If you are selling a weapon on here it usually means that the gun shops are not going to give you what you want. So make the prices resonable. If you have to have big cash because you put so much time and extra parts in then don't sell it. Keep it or keep your ego out of the sell. Good luck!

title: For Sale:  Weatherby Vanguard Series 2
postcontent:
Accurate & Affordable. The Weatherby Vanguard Series 2 Blued Synthetic represents a clear improvement over its predecessor and, given its affordable price, should prove to be just as successful. While the Vanguard Series 2 Blued varies from its predecessor in small and important ways, the basic features remain unchanged. Take the bolt, for example. Like the original’s, the Weatherby Vanguard S2 one-piece bolt has dual-opposed locking lugs with an M16-style extractor and a plunger-type ejector. Fluting on the bolt body reduces surface area and provides debris a place to migrate, preventing the bolt from binding, while three ports enable gas to escape in the event of a ruptured case or pierced primer. Knurling on the rearward-sweeping bolt handle enhances purchase. Additionally, the Weatherby Vanguard S2 bolt has a fully enclosed shroud and a cocking indicator. Staying true to the original Blued Synthetic concept, the S2 Vanguard still retains its 24" #2 contour hammer forged barrel.

The Weatherby Vanguard S2's redesigned polymer Monte Carlo-style stock has strategically placed rubberized “Griptonite” inserts at the fore-end and pistol grip for sure handling, particularly in wet conditions or when the hands are moist. The slight palm swell is also a nice touch. The Series 2 Blued is equipped with a three-position action-mounted safety; the rearmost position is “safe”; the middle position enables the bolt to be cycled for unloading while still in the “safe” mode; and fully forward allows the rifle to be fired. Perhaps the most noteworthy change is the Weatherby's newly designed 2-stage match trigger, which is factory preset at slightly more than 3 pounds, yet can be adjusted down to 2 pounds, 8 ounces.

Features
Sub-MOA Accuracy Guaranty: ensures .99" or less groups at 100 yards with premium ammunition
Match Quality 2- Stage Trigger: extremely smooth trigger adjustable down to 2.5 lbs.
New "Griptonite" Stock: Weatherby signature Monte Carlo stock with grip inserts provide a firm, non- slip surface
Full Length 24" Barrel: provides increased velocity & maximum accuracy
Forged Action, Bolt & Hammer Forged Barrel
SAKO Style Extractor for Reliability
Bolt Shroud & Gas Relief Vent Holes: for extra protection against cartridge rupture (always use the correct ammunition for your gun)
Caliber: .300WSM
Finish: Deep Blued
Steel: Forged Carbon
Action Type: Bolt

title: For Sale/Trade:  1994 lincoln town car
postcontent:
this is an extra vehicle, I have too many. I lowered the price to move it! was $1800 now $1500 or best offer
 running real good, just did a tune up on it. 
 1994 town car, 101k miles, 4.6 v8, auto, interior is in good shape but could use a detailing, tires should be good until next year, has glass pack exhaust but not too loud.

 this car STARTS EVERYTIME and goes down the road good, gas mileage should be 23 mpg highway from gov's web site http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=11080 
 i have a good, clear indiana title in my name.
 the only thing I know of that it needs is the back window motors, $45 each at napa. I changed the front ones my self in less than 30 minutes each. and the passenger side front outside turn light cover.
 I am selling it because I no longer need it. I drove this car to work while I had the motor replaced in my other car. it is dependable.
 it has new plugs, oil change, fuel filter, air filter, and crank sensor.
 the previous owner said he had the tranny rebuilt this past spring but I have no proof. but it shifts normal.
I might trade if the value is there and I can use it, but would prefer cash or some cash

 don't ask if I still have it, if the ad is here i still have it, I will remove the ad when it is gone. and no what's your bottom dollar questions, I am there, if you have an offer, make it, i will say yes, no, or more info please. Kelly blue book in good shape says $2400, $2000 in fair but I need it gone. 
 EMAILS only, no calls or texts unless we are close to a deal.

title: For Sale/Trade:  SOLD- Crimson Trace MVF-515 (red and green) and MVF-600
postcontent:
I have one each of the following brand new Crimson Trace Modular Vertical Foregrips (MVF):

MVF-515 (Red) -SOLD
MVF-515 (Green) -SOLD
MVF-600 -SOLD

These have never been mounted on a rifle, come in original box, and I’ll throw in a fresh set of batteries. If you are looking at this ad, you already know the significance and capabilities of each of these foregrips. If not, a quick Google search will give you more info than I ever could. Bottom line is that each of these are designed to be mounted on your AR-style rifle, and each offers a laser and flashlight than can be instinctively activated as you hold the weapon. The ambidextrous activation switches allow you to select the light or the laser individually or simultaneously. Prior to finalizing any purchase I’ll verify with you that everything is in working order, if requested.

I'm open to cash offers for each MVF individually, or will combine two or more for a discounted price. I'm also looking for trade offers that are roughly equal to the cash value of each MVF (or combined cash value of multiple MVFs). If you have several AR-type rifles and have been thinking about trading one, this is your chance to get a great deal. Trading an AR valued at $1200 will get you all three MVFs (which equates to a $100 discount plus one free).

MVF-515G: $500
MVF-600: $800

title: For Sale:  U.S. Remington 1903-A3
postcontent: Serial # 34784xx - this 1903 A3 rifle is chambered for .30-06 & has the correct Remington markings on the receiver and stock.  The barrel is dated 2/43 and there are no importers markings anywhere. The rifle has the Scant Stock with a protective rubber cover.  It has many service dings, dents and marks of character.  The rifle’s parkerized finish has a few service marks and rates about 80% overall condition. The rifle has a crisp bore, the bolt action operates smoothly, and trigger pull is smooth as well.  The rifle has the correct adjustable WWII rear sight, and was tapped at some point for a modern scope. This is a solid Remington 1903-A3 that would be a nice addition to your collection and/or shooter.  As with any antique firearm, we suggest you have this rifle inspected by a gunsmith.

postcontent:
This is a Service Grade (see notes below) M1 Garand recently purchased thru CMP.  The rifle is in fantastic condition and includes everything that came when purchased.  For Sales only.........no trades please.  Let me know if you need further details or more photos.  Thank you.

Whats Included:
   CMP Hard Case
   M1 Garand Rifle - Serial 5979***
   Canvas Sling
   Unopened original cleaning kit
   Clip Strip
   Manual with care instructions/take down guide/schematic
   CMP grade tag still attached
   Certificate of Authenticity

The serial number falls in the 5979*** range from Springfeild Armory.  Additional photos include stamping detail in the stock and inside the muzzle.  Despite the Service Grade rating, this rifle has a muzzle reading of +1, a throat reading of +2, and an overall G-3 grading from CMP.  See below for the broad scope of a Service Grade from CMP; this rifle exceeds those ratings.

Proper ID required for purchase.

A note from rifles purchased thru CMP:
Each M1 Garand rifle sold by CMP is an authentic U.S. Government rifle that has been inspected, headspaced, repaired if necessary and test fired for function. Each rifle is shipped with safety manual, one eight-round clip and chamber safety flag.

SERVICE GRADE: (Good to Very Good) 
Service Grade Rifles show less wear and better appearance than Field or Rack Grades. Good to very good condition. Rifle wear will be exhibited by worn and mixed colors of the parkerized finish. There may be some minor pitting on receiver and other metal parts. Wood will be either Walnut, Birch, Beech or other variety and will be basically sound but may have minor hairline cracks, dings, scratches and gouges. Wood may not match in color or type of wood. Wood may be of new production on Service Grade Garands. Bores will be generally good with only minor imperfections. The barrel crown may be nicked, but the muzzle will gauge "3 or less" and the throat erosion will gauge less than 5.

title: For Sale:  Schmidt-Rubin Swiss 1896/1911 (k11 / k31) Alpine Sport in .308
postcontent:
This was made in 1896 by the Swiss, updated in1911 by the Swiss to match their new k11 carbines,  than modified again after service for hunting practicality sometime around 1960.  If you google the Swiss straight-pull line,  you'll find that these are considered by most enthusiasts, collectors, and hunters to be the most accurate rifles ever made. By anyone, ever.  It is chambered in .308, and in my lifetime, as well as its lifetime in Switzerland, has only had match grade ammunition fired through it.  It's an absolute dream to fire, I am just ready to upgrade to the K 31.  It is 117 years old, by appearance you'd guess it was made in the late 80s. 

Opens a possible trades:  +cash on a glock 19... An over under in 12 or 20 gauge... +cash on A Swiss K 31, or possibly another bolt action in 30-06 or 308.

title: For Sale/Trade:  WW II German SA Dagger
postcontent:
Really fine example of a WW II SA Dagger.  This is authentic.  Blade stamped: HAMMESFAHR CIE. with horizontal swimmer and *SOLIGEN*.  Obverse side of handle has original emblems with deep relief and detail.  Made by E. P. & S with emblem inplace.  Lower tang of knife is stamped: No, which is the Nordsee District.  The leather clasp is not stamped.  There is slight finish peel on the scabbard and a dent on the pommel which is normal for a field use item.
Note:  This is being offered as a wartime memorbilia piece and does not reflect any opinions or beliefs of the seller.
